main_text:
Issues concerning scientific explanation have been a focus of
philosophical attention from Pre-Socratic times through the modern
period. However, modern discussion really begins with the development
of the Deductive-Nomological (DN) model. This model has had
many advocates (including Popper 1959, Braithwaite 1953, Gardiner,
1959, Nagel 1961) but unquestionably the most detailed and influential
statement is due to Carl Hempel (1942, 1965a, and Hempel & Oppenheim 1948).
These papers and the reaction to them have structured subsequent
discussion concerning scientific explanation to an extraordinary
degree. After some general remarks by way of background and
orientation
 (Section 1),
 this entry describes the DN model and its extensions, and
then turns to some well-known objections
 (Section 2).
 It next describes a variety of subsequent attempts to develop
alternative models of explanation, including Wesley Salmon’s
Statistical Relevance
 (Section 3)
 and Causal Mechanical
 (Section 4)
 models, Unificationist models due to Michael Friedman and
Philip Kitcher
 (Section 5),
 and Pragmatic theories found in the work of van Fraassen
 (Section 6).
 Section 7 provides a summary and discusses directions for future
work. This article thus discusses treatments of scientific explanation
up to the end of the twentieth century.
